I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In December 2004, the Government of Bangladesh (the Government) requested that the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide technical assistance (TA) for the corporatization of the 
Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB). ADB Management approved the TA concept 
paper in April 20051 and a fact-finding mission was conducted from 9 to 16 May 2005. An 
understanding  was  reached  with  the  Government  on  the  TA’s  impact  and  outcome, 
methodology and key activities, cost and financing, implementation arrangements, and terms of 
reference. The Government approved the Technical Assistance Project Proforma in April 2004 
and confirmed the aide-memoire of the fact-finding mission on 31 May 2005. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Inadequate  electricity  supply  and  very  low  levels  of  access  to  electricity  are  major 
constraints  to  Bangladesh’s  economic  growth.  Only  about  one  third  of  the  population  has 
access  to  electricity  and  per  capita  generation  is  among  the  lowest  in  the  world,  about 
155 kilowatt-hours (kWh) per year. At the same time, demand is rising: consumption grew at an 
average annual rate of 8.2% from FY1994 to FY2004, and it is forecast to grow at about 8% per 
year  for  the  next  10  years.  The  current  dependable  generating  capacity  is  about  3,950 
megawatts (MW) and, during FY2004, load in the range of 8–540 MW was shed for a total of 
951 hours over 232 days. Bangladesh is facing an anticipated shortfall of about 2,500 MW of 
generating capacity over the next 5 years, hence the need to attract more domestic and foreign 
investment to meet demand. 
 
3.  As well as the lack of physical infrastructure, Bangladesh’s power sector has faced 
critical  financial  challenges,  including  insolvency  (e.g.,  BPDB  owes  the  Government  Tk56 
billion). The power sector has also suffered from poor accounting practices, which have resulted 
in delayed account and audit completion, overvaluation of assets, underestimation of expenses, 
and inadequate provision for bad debts. Poor governance—low billing collection ratios and high 
system losses—has hampered the power sector’s development and financial sustainability. 
 
4.  In 1994, the Government adopted a policy paper entitled Power Sector Reforms in 
Bangladesh (PSRB), which was formulated in consultation with major development partners in 
the power sector. According to the PSRB, the long-term structure of the power sector will 
feature  (i)  a  separation  of  sector  regulation  and  operation;  (ii)  autonomy  and  commercial 
orientation of the sector entities; (iii) unbundling of generation, transmission, and distribution; 
and (iv) more private sector participation. Under this structure, power transmission will remain in 
the public sector, while generation and distribution assets will be both publicly and privately 
owned. The objective is to eliminate monopolies and foster competition, in an effort to promote 
commercial discipline and good customer service. A new regulatory authority will be established 
for  (i)  setting  electricity  tariffs  and  determining  the  corresponding  performance  norms;  (ii) 
collecting, verifying, and disseminating sector statistics; (iii) reviewing and approving long-term 
power planning; (iv) creating and maintaining a nondiscriminatory and commercial business 
environment  in  the  sector;  and  (v)  adjudicating  disputes  between  sector  entities.  These 
restructuring reforms are designed to attract more investment in the power sector and they are 
reinforced and prioritized in the policy agenda of the Government’s draft 2005–2007 poverty 
reduction strategy paper for the power sector. 
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 25 April 2005.

2   
5.  Bangladesh’s  power  sector  is  under  the  Ministry  of  Power,  Energy  and  Mineral 
Resources  (MPEMR),  which  wholly  owns  and  supervises  BPDB,  Dhaka  Electric  Supply 
Authority (DESA), and the Rural Electrification Board (REB). Until the late 1990s, BPDB was 
responsible for national generation and most transmission, as well as distribution in district 
towns, municipalities, and some rural areas; DESA was responsible for distribution in the Dhaka 
area. At present, about 70 rural electric cooperatives—organized, initially funded, and monitored 
by REB—are in charge of distribution in most rural areas. As part of the power sector reform, 
new public sector entities—such as the Power Grid Company of Bangladesh Limited (PGCB), 
Dhaka Electric Supply Company Limited (DESCO), West Zone Power Distribution Company 
Limited (WZPDCL), and Ashuganj Power Station Company Limited (APSCL)—as well as private 
sector independent power producers—such as the Rural Power Company Limited and the 
Electricity Generation Company of Bangladesh—have been constituted. PGCB has taken over 
all BPDB’s transmission assets and DESCO has secured DESA’s distribution assets in Mirpur 
and Gulshan, Dhaka. WZPDCL and APSCL have taken over BPDB’s distribution assets in the 
west  and  generation  assets  in  Ashuganj  Power  Station,  respectively.  BPDB  is  currently 
responsible  for  about  60%  of  electricity  generation  and  about  30%  of  distribution.  The 
Bangladesh Energy Regulatory Commission (BERC) was established in March 2004 under the 
new Energy Regulatory Commission Act 2003.2  
 
6.  The aforementioned changes in the business environment and organizational set-up 
yielded  major  improvements  in  the  operational  and  financial  performance  of  power  sector 
entities. For example, overall system losses (based on gross generation) decreased from 37% 
(FY1994) to 27% (FY2004), while billing collection rates rose from 80% (1994) to over 90% 
(2004). The Government’s reform initiatives culminated in the Cabinet Committee on Economic 
Affairs’ approval of corporatization plans for BPDB (January 2004), BPDB’s northwest zone 
distribution network (March 2004), and DESA (July 2004). 
 
7.  ADB  is  a  long-term  lead  development  partner  of  the  Government  in  power  sector 
restructuring  and  reform.  ADB  supports  the  Government’s  implementation  of  the  PSRB  in 
promoting  good  governance  at  the  sectoral  and  corporate  levels.  At  the  sectoral  level, 
governance is to be improved through (i) predictability—long-term planning, codification of rules 
and  regulations,  and  independence  of  regulatory  processes;  (ii)  transparency—systematic 
dissemination of relevant sector information, public hearings, and discussions on issues before 
they  are  decided;  and  (iii)  accountability—the  cause–effect  structure  of  incentives.  At  the 
corporate level, governance is to be enhanced through (i) corporatization, (ii) independence of 
the boards of directors from the Government, (iii) introduction of a work-based pay structure, 
(iv) defined delegation of powers to staff, (v) computerized management information systems 
(MIS), and (vi) commercialization of activities. ADB has approved three TA projects relevant to 
this reform: corporatization of the Ashuganj Power Station,3 BPDB’s west zone distribution 
system,4  and    DESA.5  ADB  is  also  assisting  corporatization  of  BPDB’s  northwest  zone 
distribution network under a loan.6 The World Bank is financing a TA project for financial

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will assist the Government and BPDB to (i) corporatize BPDB as a holding 
company, (ii) introduce appropriate financial and management systems in the new company, 
and  (iii)  integrate  the new  company  into  the  power  sector  network.  It  will  define  the  new 
company’s relationship with subsidiaries and other sector entities. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  By the time the consultants are fielded, it is expected that the necessary documents for 
corporatization of BPDB (such as the memorandum and articles of association) will have been 
filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies of Bangladesh, and the task force will have 
been  established.  The  consultants  will  work  jointly  with  the  task  force  so  that  task  force 
personnel will be involved throughout the TA. All TA deliverables will emerge as being fully 
“owned” by the task force.  
 
10.  The TA will be divided into two phases. Phase I (about 4 months) will develop the overall 
approach to the corporatization of BPDB, creating further subsidiaries, and defining the legal 
and accounting formalities for transferring BPDB assets and liabilities to the new company. 
Phase II will develop more concrete options and recommendations for the corporatization of 
BPDB, detail the new company’s MIS, and assist in the corporatization and initial operations of 
the  new  company.  The  TA’s  key  activities  will  be  to  devise  appropriate  strategies  for 
(i) evaluating assets, (ii) establishing a viable financing plan, (iii) formulating personnel policies, 
(iv) organizing the transfer of assets and staff to the new company, (v) organizing the voluntary 
separation scheme for eligible BPDB staff, (vi) examining and organizing the sale of BPDB’s 
shares in its subsidiary companies, and (vii) implementing MIS. The consultants will coordinate 
closely  with  teams  from  other  relevant  studies—including  the  ADB  TA  projects  on  the 
corporatization of DESA and preparing the Power Sector Development Program II, and the 
World  Bank’s  TA  for  power  sector  reform—to  ensure  smooth  implementation  and  non-
duplication of work. Phase II will begin near the completion of Phase I. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,030,000 equivalent, comprising $590,000 in 
foreign  exchange  costs  and  $440,000  equivalent  in  local  currency  costs.  The  full  foreign 
exchange costs of $590,000 equivalent and $210,000 equivalent of the local currency costs for 
a total of $800,000 will be financed on a grant basis from the ADB’s Japan Special Fund, funded 
by the Government of Japan. The Government will contribute the remaining $230,000 of local 
currency costs in kind, as office space and facilities, counterpart staff, local transportation, and 
administrative  and  secretarial  support.  Detailed  cost  estimates  and  financing  plans  are  in 
Appendix 2.

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The Power Division of the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral Resources (MPEMR) 
will be the Executing Agency for the TA. To enable smooth implementation of the study and 
transfer of knowledge, a task force with suitably qualified and experienced staff will be set up 
before the consultants are fielded. MPEMR will provide, free of charge to the consultants’ team, 
office accommodation and facilities, and transport within Bangladesh. MPEMR will assist the 
consultants in data gathering, preliminary analysis, and report writing. The entire work, including 
report writing, will be done in Bangladesh to maximize transfer of knowledge. The consultants 
will make their own arrangements for personal computers and other facilities for producing 
reports. 
 
13.  The  consultants  will  purchase  the  equipment  listed  in  Appendix  2  following  ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. Although the guidelines allow for direct purchase, consultants 
should seek quotations from at least three suppliers. All equipment purchased under the TA 
should be used by the consultants and MPEMR during the TA, and handed over to MPEMR 
when the TA is completed. The list of equipment will be finalized during the inception stage in 
consultation with MPEMR, and will be submitted to ADB for review and concurrence prior to 
purchase. 
 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months from October 2005 to October 2006. ADB 
will  select  and  engage  an  international  consulting  firm,  supported  by  associated  domestic 
consultants,  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  The  simplified 
technical proposal and quality- and cost-based selection will be applied to select the consulting 
firm. The TA will require 20 person-months of international consulting services and 40 person-
months of domestic consulting services. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  The TA will require input from an international consulting firm with expertise in corporate 
restructuring and governance, human resources, MIS, law, and commerce. The international 
consultants will be supported by domestic consultants in the above areas. The international 
consulting firm will propose a suitable combination of expertise and allocation of person-months, 
and appoint an international consultant as team leader—a technical expert responsible for the 
overall management and coordination of the TA study.  
 
16.  The consultant will submit an inception report (1 month after appointment), a midterm 
report (after 6 months), a draft final report (after 10 months), and a final report (after 12 months). 
The inception report will detail initial findings and the consultant’s proposed action plan. The first 
tripartite meeting among the Government, ADB and the consultants will review the inception 
report in Dhaka within 3 weeks of receiving it. A midterm report will describe the TA’s progress, 
person-months utilized, problems encountered, and proposed revision of the work plan; and will 
incorporate detailed reports on completion of Phase I activities. A draft final report will detail the 
consultants’ findings and recommendations. The second and third tripartite meetings will review 
the midterm and draft final reports, respectively. The consultants will organize (i) a workshop 
after the second tripartite meeting to brief stakeholders and receive their feedback on the 
corporatization program, MIS, and procedures to be implemented, and (ii) a seminar at the 
conclusion of the TA to disseminate the findings. The final report will be submitted within 4 
weeks after the tripartite review of the draft final report.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bangladesh for the Corporatization of the Bangladesh Power Development 
Board, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
1.  The consultants will work closely to corporatize BPDB with the Ministry of Power, Energy 
and Mineral Resources (MPEMR); Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB); and the 
Government-established task force. The consultants will undertake, but not be limited to, the 
tasks outlined below. 
 
A.  Phase I 
 
  1.  Legal and Commercial Aspects of Corporatization 
 
2.  The legal and commercial corporatization tasks will comprise all procedural, legal, and 
operational requirements to establish a corporation, effect the transfer, and insure that the 
company has the rights and authorities needed to conduct the business. The tasks will include 
the following: 
 
(i)  Review the memorandum and articles of association for registration of the 
corporatized  company,  and  determine  what,  if  any,  adjustments  are 
required. 
 
(ii)  Review  the  current  Bangladeshi  legal  and  regulatory  framework 
applicable to BPDB’s corporatization. 
 
(iii)  Review BPDB’s existing organization and management structure. Assess 
management  systems,  including  financial  management,  personnel 
management, technical operations, and inventory management. 
 
(iv)  Review all relevant studies, reports, and policies related to corporatization 
of power sector entities in Bangladesh, including the final report of ADB’s 
TA3343-BAN: Corporatization of the Ashuganj Power Station and report 
on  Country  Assistance  Program  Evaluation  for  Bangladesh  (CAPE: 
BAN2003-03). 
 
(v)  Propose an appropriate methodology and approach to corporatization of 
BPDB as a holding company, based on the review process. This should 
include a timetable and schedule of activities to be completed, and a clear 
assignment  of  duties  and  responsibilities  to  ensure  each  step  is 
completed. The methodology should include legal as well as physical 
transfer of assets, personnel, and liabilities. 
 
(vi)  Determine what, if any, additional legal documents and/or instruments 
would be required to corporatize BPDB as a holding company. 
 
(vii)  Recommend  the  roles  and  functions  of  the  proposed  BPDB  holding 
company. 
 
(viii)  Define  the  functions  and  responsibilities  of  the  new  company  after 
corporatization, and the relations of the BPDB holding company and its 
subsidiaries with other entities in the power sector.

2.  Accounting and Financial Management 
 
3.  The scope of accounting and financial management tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Review  of  BPDB’s  accounting  system,  internal  control  policies,  and 
procedures; recommend required improvements, if any; 
 
(ii)  Review  of  BPDB’s  general  ledgers  to  identify  relevant  accounting 
transactions and balances; 
 
(iii)  Complete a physical inventory count, including fixed assets and inventory, 
with assets categorized as operational or administrative; 
 
(iv)  Review  of  BPDB’s  financial  structure,  such  as  assets  and  liability 
structure,  debt/equity  ratio,  existing  contracts  and  obligations,  and 
investment  needs;  identify  issues  related  to  transfer  of  assets  and 
liabilities to the corporatized BPDB; and recommend actions to address 
the issues; 
 
(v)  Appraise and recommend adjustments to assets and liabilities, estimate 
the necessary working capital for the corporatized company, and prepare 
a proposal for the funding of the working capital requirements; 
 
(vi)  Prepare  the  disposal  and/or  divesture  plan  for  non-core  business 
activities, if any; and

(vii)  Prepare financial projections for the corporatized company for the next 5

  3.  Human Resources Management 
 
4.  The scope of human resources management in Phase I is to carry out due diligence of 
BPDB’s  organizational  structure,  staffing  issues,  and  employment  rules  and  personnel 
procedures. The tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Develop  a  realistic  staffing  plan  for  the  corporatized  BPDB,  assess 
BPDB’s  existing  staffing  capabilities,  and  evaluate  the  impact  of 
corporatization on BPDB’s existing staff; 
 
(ii)  Prepare  draft  job  descriptions  and  qualification  requirements  for  key 
positions in the corporatized company; 
 
(iii)  Propose a draft salary structure for the corporatized BPDB; 
 
(iv)  Identify  bottlenecks  for  transfer  of  employees  from  BPDB  to  the 
corporatized company and propose solutions; and 
 
(v)  Prepare a needs analysis of management training for the new managers. 
 
B.  Phase II 
 
5.  Building  on  the  work  conducted  in  phase  I,  and  considering  feedback  from  the 
Government and ADB, as well as the outcome of the workshop, the consultant will undertake 
the following activities during phase II. 
 
  1.  Development of Management Information System (MIS) 
 
6.  The consultants will  
 
(i)  determine  MIS  requirements  for  the  corporatized  company,  including 
human resources management, physical asset management, inventory 
management, and financial management; 
 
(ii)  design MIS, including determination of daily and monthly MIS reporting 
formats to enable management of the corporatized company to focus on 
key issues; 
 
(iii)  determine  hardware  and  software  requirements  (specifications  and 
budgets) for MIS implementation; and 
 
(iv)  determine staffing requirements and training needs of MIS personnel for 
the corporatized company.
